So many commenters seem to forget that a huge proportion of the recent deficit increase is the result of decreased tax revenue in this economic crisis. In other words, even with no stimulus spending at all the deficit would have increased dramatically since the recession hit in late 2008, and it would have done so under any president and Congress that didn't instantly slash social security, medicare, and defense spending the minute the recession hit. It is wrong, and highly disingenuous, to pretend that the deficit increases under Obama are substantially the result of Obama spending increases. Furthermore, the relatively modest Obama stimulus spending did, in fact, mitigate the potential impact of a deeper recession -- i.e. what would have been an even greater negative impact on government tax revenue as well as on jobs.

I'm not an economist, but these basic facts are readily available to anyone who can read -- or at least who can read without ideological blinders.

The Republican nomination battle of 2011 was, almost from the start, an inter-party struggle between the establishment, which supported Romney as the candidate best qualified to beat Obama, and the hard right, which takes in the Tea Party people, the Koch brothers and their big-money allies, and the evangelicals. The latter lost not because they didn't have a majority of the Republican electorate -- they always did and do now -- but because there was no candidate around whom they could unite. Everybody got a shot -- Bachmann first, then Perry, then Cain, then Gingrich, and now Santorum. The problem was that no poll EVER showed a hard right candidate as having more than a long shot's chance of beating Obama. And when the American electorate rejects not one but FIVE people competing from the same point in the political spectrum, more is at work than weak candidates. The American people don't want a hard right President -- it's that simple.

This is a great description of why the deficit and national debt are far from the most important issues facing the US right now.

But there is a third point to be made, and that is that focusing on reducing the deficit through cutting spending may actually be increasing the deficit. The reasoning behind this counter-intuitive point is that one of the main causes for the increase in the deficit over the past few years has been the decline in tax revenues and increase in social safety net spending that was triggered by the 2008 Bush Recession. Recovery from that recession would help government bring in more revenue, and would reduce the number of people who need to receive unemployment benefits, Medicaid, etc. But with both consumers and corporations reluctant to spend - consumers because they are still digging out from the housing meltdown and are uncertain about their job prospects, and corporations due to a lack of demand - the only way to get the economy fully moving again is federal stimulus spending. That may cause a short term increase in the deficit, but in the long term such spending would likely decrease the debt. Unfortunately, the GOP, which is looking to hold our economy down through at least the 2012 elections, understand the importance of stimulus spending to economic recovery and it is why they are trying to distract us all with talk of debt.

"A demonstration for an underground transit system in New York City was first built by Alfred Ely Beach in 1869. His Beach Pneumatic Transit only extended 312 feet (95 m) under Broadway in Lower Manhattan and exhibited his idea for a subway propelled by pneumatic tube technology.

The first underground line of the subway opened on October 27, 1904, almost 35 years after the opening of the first elevated line in New York City, which became the IRT Ninth Avenue Line. The Great Blizzard of 1888 helped demonstrate the benefits of an underground transportation system. The oldest structure still in use opened in 1885 as part of the BMT Lexington Avenue Line in Brooklyn and is now part of the BMT Jamaica Line. The oldest right-of-way, that of the BMT West End Line, was in use in 1863 as a steam railroad called the Brooklyn, Bath and Coney Island Rail Road."

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_City_Subway#History

Which begs the question:

How were the German and Japanese underground mass-transit systems doing in 1904 ?

The comment by one reader that "the NYC subway system is crap compared to similar systems that are more current, cleaner and better staffed like those in Japan, Germany and the UK" is spot on.

The real question, however, is WHY we are falling behind other countries. There is a reason why public transit (both locally within cities and over longer distances, such as high-speed rail, etc.) is so much better in other industrialized countries than it is here. Those countries actually invest in their infrastructure, while we seem to think we can skimp on funding and still have decent public transport. Not so. This is a long term problem we need to address.

Everyone complaining needs to realize that you get what you pay for. And no, privatization is not the answer. Adequate funding is.
